headline.main: Study Finds Strokes More Common Than Previously Thought

docs.abstract: Researchers at University of Cincinnati report that about 700,000 Americans a year suffer strokes, about 40 percent more than indicated by Framingham Heart Study; that study focused on a virtually white, middle-cass town, while new study is based on all strokes recorded for a year in Cincinnati area, where 14 percent of population is black; another study projects that number of strokes could double in next half-century (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Strokes hit about 200,000 more Americans a year than commonly believed, a new study has found. It tried to correct previous research by looking at black neighborhoods instead of just white communities. The study, with other research, suggests that about 700,000 Americans a year suffer strokes, or about 40 percent more than the accepted estimate, and that the figures could double in the next half-century.
